response: Regularly review your credit card statements to ensure all transactions are legitimate. Report any discrepancies or unfamiliar charges to your bank immediately.
Set up transaction alerts on your credit card for a certain threshold amount. This way, you'll be notified of any large or unusual transactions in real-time.
Whenever possible, enable two-factor authentication for your credit card transactions. This adds an extra layer of security, making it more difficult for unauthorized users to access your account.
If you suspect a fraudulent transaction, contact your bank's fraud department immediately. They can guide you on how to dispute the charge and may block your card to prevent further unauthorized use.
Change your credit card password and PIN if you suspect fraudulent activity. Ensure that your security information, such as email and phone number, associated with the account is up-to-date.
Monitor your credit report for any suspicious activity. You are entitled to a free annual credit report from major credit bureaus. Report any inaccuracies promptly to the credit reporting agencies.
